headline: Gary Neville rejects popular Man United 'excuse' ahead of Premier League season
body: Former Manchester United captain Gary Neville has insisted that injuries cannot be used as an excuse this season despite a torrid run of luck in the treatment room this summer.

Last season was disastrous for United in terms of injuries with veteran centre-back Jonny Evans forced to cover in defence more often than anyone would have liked. The hope was that this year United would turn a corner on injuries but that has not been the case to date.

New signing Leny Yoro was forced off during pre-season against Arsenal and will be out for months. Meanwhile, Rasmus Hojlund has missed the start of the campaign as have Luke Shaw, Tyrell Malacia and Victor Lindelof.

While many fans will have sympathy for the injury issues at the club, Neville has dismissed these concerns as nothing more than an excuse. Speaking during co-commentary at Old Trafford for the clash with Fulham, he explained: "Still getting injuries at full-back aren't they?

"It's something that can't be used as an excuse this season. If they keep getting injuries again then you must say there is something structurally wrong whether it's bringing the players in or they're doing something in training that's stressing them too much or under-training.
"I'm not sure. They can't hide behind that anymore."

United began their Premier League season at Old Trafford on Friday evening with the visit of Fulham. The Reds are set to have their sqaud stretched to the limits again this campaign as they compete not only domestically in the top flight, FA Cup and Carabao Cup but also in the Europa League.

headline: Eric Cantona hijacks Man United vs Fulham broadcast in bizarre stunt
body: Former Manchester United striker Eric Cantona has starred in a bizarre advertisement that saw him hijack Premier League coverage of the Reds' clash with Fulham.

In an unusual stunt that may never be repeated, Cantona joined host Julia Stuart and fellow ex-Reds midfielder Owen Hargreaves in the studio for analysis of the opening game of the season. All seemed normal until Stuart asked the Frenchman: "What can you and the millions of Manchester United fans around the world expect; what will be unfolding as the season progresses on their television sets?"

This question appeared to spark something in Cantona as he sarcastically chuckled: "Television," before taking off his microphone, jacket and tie and performing a passionate rant directly into the camera. "We call this the beautiful game but how many people in this world do not even own a television. What of them? How do we sell this to them?" He began.

"To be truly beautiful as a game, it should be everywhere. Should not be stuck on a wall or just in a bar. It must fly. And my friends, no one should believe that the Premier League is out of their league.
"And this marks the beginning. The revolution has begun."

The feed to the studio then cut out and when it returned Cantona was leading the broadcast and triumphantly declared: "The revolution will not be televised; the revolution will be live." Of course, this was not some sensational plot by Cantona to monopolise Premier League coverage but was actually an advertisement promoting a new streaming surface for the division in Africa, Showmax.
For the first time, supporters in Africa will be able to watch their clubs via their mobile phones instead of exclusively on television.

headline: Managing Man United - De Ligt deal, Ten Hag transfer policy and midfield priority
body: Manchester United’s eighth-place finish last term - a Premier League record low - has put the impetus on INEOUS and Erik ten Hag to bring new recruits in this summer.

Earlier in the summer, United welcomed 18-year-old centre-back Leny Yoro from Ligue 1 side Lille as well as Joshua Zirkzee - who impressed in Serie A with Bologna last term, scoring 11 goals in 34 league appearances.

As ever, there were several links and reported bids for Everton’s Jarrad Branthwaite but the Toffees rejected United’s approach and he looks set for another season at Goodison Park. However, the arrival of former Ajax and Bayern Munich central defender Matthijs de Ligt should sure up United’s defence - last season Ten Hag’s side conceded 58 goals - finishing on a negative goal difference.

In previous years, United have pursued older, experienced players such as Cristiano Ronaldo, Raphael Varane and Casemiro - who tend to have a low sell-on value and struggle with fitness in Varane’s case.

This window has been different - the average age of the players acquired is 23 with Noussair Mazraoi the oldest at 26. This is a step in the right direction, even if the transfers do not go to plan these players will retain or even increase their value - which for United, creates a more sustainable policy around transfers.

After being reintegrated into Ten Hag’s squad after rebuilding their relationship, Sancho has been linked with a move to Paris Saint-Germain despite featuring in pre-season preparations ahead of the Premier League season.

According to Fabrizio Romano, the winger’s representatives were in talks with the French side over a potential transfer in July but no formal bids were forthcoming. It is thought that no decision has been made yet with other options available for a move.

United have been linked with the midfielder all summer and the player is reported to be keen on the move to Old Trafford. The 23-year-old was left out of PSG’s squad for their trip to Le Havre - which could be an indicator that a move is close.

The Uruguayan featured in 25 league games last season but looks out of favour in Paris. Ugarte is a defensive midfielder - a position United are relatively short in with Casemiro aging and likely to have his game time managed. At 23, this could be a savvy move for all parties involved.

The 'number six' position should be a priority in the final weeks of the transfer window. Scott McTominay will be able to play a role but has developed into a box-to-box player rather than a 'destroyer'. With the UEFA Europa League and the two domestic cup competitions to consider, a defensive midfielder is a must for Ten Hag.

headline: Gary Neville starts new job during Man United's Premier League opener vs Fulham
body: Gary Neville is set to become a familiar face on US television, joining NBC for the 2024/25 Premier League season as a pundit.

Since hanging up his boots in 2011, the former Manchester United defender has been a stalwart of British football broadcasting. He is now poised to charm American audiences, with NBC scooping him up for their coverage.
NBC trumpeted their new signing, stating: "NBC Sports is proud to welcome Gary Neville to the team as a special contributor throughout the 2024/25 season!"
According to the network, Neville will focus on Sunday game analyses, but he is juggling his commitments with Sky Sports on Friday evening, appearing on NBC during an advert break.

Neville is expected to continue to be a lead pundit with Sky Sports, as his NBC role is described as a "collaboration with Sky Sports." and both broadcasters are owned by American giant Comcast. His move to NBC could see a spike in viewership, building on the broadcaster's recent success including a record-breaking 'Championship Sunday' viewership of nearly three million.

Amid these broadcasting shifts, viewers can also anticipate several on-pitch changes confirmed ahead of tonight's Premier League kick-off. One of the alterations is the number of substitutes permitted to warm up at any one time.

Last season, it was three, but this term it has been raised to five per team. Another modification pertains to how additional time is calculated, with minutes for delays caused by goal celebrations only added on if the celebrations exceed 30 seconds.

A minor adjustment in the multiball rule now allows ball assistants positioned behind the goal to directly hand the ball back to 'keepers. United kick off their new campaign against Fulham tonight at 8pm.

headline: Avram Glazer spotted at Old Trafford for Man United vs Fulham
body: Manchester United co-owner Avram Glazer has returned to Old Trafford for what is thought to be the first time in two years for the Reds' Premier League opener against Fulham.

The Glazer family have rarely been spotted at the Theatre of Dreams since opinion of the ownership soured. For the past few years, United fans have protested against the American family for their perceived neglect of the club.

These protests became less frequent in the second half of last season when it was announced that Sir Jim Ratcliffe and Ineos had bought a minority stake in the club. The English billionaire has since taken over the football side of the club with the Glazers taking a back seat.

While the Glazers have been spotted for the most recent trips to Wembley Stadium, they have been scarcely spotted in Manchester. Until tonight that is, with the 63-year-old seen inside the ground prior to kick off.

His last appearance at Old Trafford was in August 2022 as United lost their opening match of the season at home to Graham Potter's Brighton and Hove Albion. During that match, there were vocal protests against his family's ownership.

While Glazer is at the match, it is expected that Ratcliffe will not be in attendance for the opener. United have handed out just the one full debut this evening as full-back Noussair Mazraoui starts against Fulham.
Matthijs de Ligt has been named among the substitutes as has Joshua Zirkzee. Meanwhile, French defender Leny Yoro is missing due to his injury picked up on tour.

headline: Man United get fresh FFP boost as chief under pressure to secure transfer
body: Manchester United have received fresh hope of selling Victor Lindelof this summer with Eintracht Frankfurt eyeing a move for the Swedish defender.

Following the arrival of Matthijs de Ligt this week, pressure has intensified at Old Trafford to sell Lindelof this summer to recoup some money back for their Financial Fair Play (FFP) commitments. MEN Sport understands the Reds have been actively looking to sell the 30-year-old due to his contract running out at the end of next year.

While Lindelof is not in hot water with the powers that be, he is seen as a player who would not be offered a new deal in 2025 so the time is now to recoup some money. So far, interest in the centre-back has been limited but that could be changing.

According to Frankfurter Rundschau, the Bundesliga club's director of football Markus Krosche is experiencing pressure to bring in a centre-back as options in this position are thin on the ground. It is understood one target Frankfurt had their eye on this window decided to go elsewhere in Krosche is believed to be scrambling to find a replacement.

On that list is Lindelof who has evidently been pushed down the pecking order after the arrivals of De Ligt and Leny Yoro. Frankfurt are thought to be in a strong position to pay for the Swede having bagged £38m for Willian Pacho after his switch to PSG last week.

Lindelof could be missing from the bench tonight when United open their Premier League campaign against Fulham at Old Trafford. He has not featured since the defeat to Liverpool in pre-season where he picked up an injury and Erik ten Hag did not provide an update on his fitness during yesterday's press conference.

headline: Man United's dream Youssouf Fofana transfer alternative clear and it's not Manuel Ugarte
body: Manchester United have a clear transfer alternative to Youssouf Fofana with his move from AS Monaco to AC Milan in the process of being finalised. The France international was identified as an option to strengthen Erik ten Hag's midfield alongside the likes of Manuel Ugarte, Sander Berge and Martin Zubimendi.

With his contract in France set to expire in 2025, a summer departure for Fofana was expected with AC Milan quickly opening talks. Though a deal stalled as the two clubs attempted to agree on a fee, the latest bid from the Italian club was accepted with a medical scheduled for him to complete the switch.

As the 26-year-old is now off the table, with Zubimendi also likely to remain at Real Sociedad given his decision to turn down an approach from Liverpool, options for Ten Hag and Ineos are dwindling. Ugarte and Berge are still on the market but they are very different midfielders to Fofana, so it really depends on the profile United want.

With Fofana much more of a box-to-box midfielder, there are several options available to United if they wish to pursue a player with obvious similarities to AC Milan's newest arrival. Courtesy of stats gathered by Macro Football, Fofana is nearly an identical midfielder, in terms of strengths, to new AS Roma signing Enzo Le Fee.

Of course as he has recently arrived in Italy from Rennes in a deal worth £19.6million (€23m), any chance of a move over the coming windows is unlikely. Maxence Caqueret, however, has been at Lyon for the past four years and could be perfect for United's midfield.

The 24-year-old has a contract until 2027 and is currently valued at £17million (€20m), as per transfermarkt. If United decide to pursue a deal and can reach an agreement around that figure, it would be an absolute steal.

headline: Manchester United's three-step plan for Joshua Zirkzee pays off vs Fulham
body: Joshua Zirkzee re-emerged for the second half long before the rest of his teammates to take his place back on the bench and was hardly noticed. They noticed him at full-time.

No striker and no goals. Once Manchester United had a striker on, they got their goal. Zirkzee's integration has now been vindicated with a goalscoring Old Trafford debut, just like the returning Dutchman in the dugout.

Zirkzee and Alejandro Garnacho started warming up within five minutes of the restart. Eight minutes later, Erik ten Hag hollered their names. Ruud van Nistelrooy was stood next to Ten Hag when Garnacho and Zirkzee combined for United's winner.

Zirkzee holidayed in Los Angeles when United were based there yet reported for training at Carrington, He was unused against Manchester City in the Community Shield. The wait was worth it for the 70,000 optimistic United matchgoers.

Ten Hag summoned his compatriot on the hour. The £36.5million Zirkzee was thoroughly briefed by the new set-piece coach Andreas Georgson yet was rarely in sync with his new teammates until the moment it mattered. Zirkzee is the fourth United Dutchman to score on his Old Trafford bow after Jordi Cruyff, Van Nistelrooy, Robin van Persie, Alexander Buttner and Donny van de Beek.

Scoring without performing is an invaluable knack. It would be an exaggeration to say Zirkzee did not perform before he connected with Garnacho's cross yet he was well marshalled by Fulham up until that point. He deftly converted one of United's more difficult chances on a night they created clearer openings.

The absence of a focal point ought to have been rendered moot. There were three glaring chances for Bruno Fernandes and Mason Mount, United's two most central attackers. United passed up presentable opportunities against Manchester City in the Community Shield and Liverpool in South Carolina earlier this month. They won the one that mattered.

Ten Hag resorted to throwing on Scott McTominay, a veteran of several salvage operations last season. Zirkzee appeared to prod the ball ahead of McTominay and it was immediately unclear who had got the final touch. The unflappable Zirkzee's celebration was borderline muted.
United ended last season with a minus goal difference and are positive again. Positivity reigns again.

The palpable optimism at kick-off had gradually ebbed until the debutant's 87th-minute intervention. United players applauded all four corners of the ground to a chorus of "Take me home, United road". The regulars are happy to be home.

Ten Hag, clad in a two-piece suit with ankle socks and trainers, started jotting notes before the 20-minute mark. He repeatedly referenced United's "game model" during pre-season yet this was not a model performance.

Casemiro waned as the intensity increased yet briefly rallied to play two perfect passes for Fernandes, who struck bluntly on both occasions. Casemiro now thrives more in the final third than his own, an additional incentive for United to add a defensive midfielder.

The cumbersome Casemiro did not even attempt to bust a gut when Andreas Pereira botched Fulham's pivotal two-on-one at 0-0. As much of an asset as the Brazilian evidently is in the final third, he cannot be entrusted as the United sentry over the next nine months.

The game was played around United's playmaker, Mount. Mount is at his most impressive off the ball, pressing and harrying opponents. His work on it leaves him vulnerable whenever Ten Hag adds a striker to the starting XI. He was hooked on the hour.
Mount attempted to commit a cynical foul before he was booked for halting a breakaway. He had the nearest of United's one-on-ones yet prodded the ball at Leno.

The new brains trust was sat in one of the front rows of the directors' box: Dave Brailsford, Omar Berrada, Dan Ashworth, Jason Wilcox... and Kees Vos. Ten Hag's agent was flanked by the United manager's wife, Bianca, and son, Nigel.

Towards the back was Avram Glazer on only his third visit to Old Trafford in the past five years. The co-chairman is by far the most visible of the six siblings and with Sir Jim Ratcliffe now the face of this new United, Old Trafford is not the danger zone it was for a Glazer this time last year. There was still a fleeting rendition of "We want Glazers out".

United's four new signings were paraded before kick-off. The loudest reaction for an individual was reserved for Garnacho as he embarked on a warm-up. United missed his dynamism and directness in the goalless first half and it yielded Zirkzee's winner.
Ten Hag retreated to the dugout after spending the majority of the first half in the technical area to consult his new Dutch sounding boards in the absence of former assistant Mitchell van der Gaag.

The United players had emerged for their warm-up to the sound of I Wanna Be Adored by The Stone Roses. Van Nistelrooy followed with his own chorus of "Ruuuuud". Younger fans inside the ground will now realise how adored he was as a player.
Van Nistelrooy will have felt that when he embraced Ten Hag.

headline: I saw what Ruud van Nistelrooy did to Joshua Zirkzee at full-time - Man United fans will love it
body: Manchester United made a winning start to the 2024/25 Premier League season at Old Trafford on Friday night, beating Fulham 1-0.
Forward Joshua Zirkzee, who was recruited from Bologna last month, stepped off the bench to mark his debut with a goal. He steered home Alejandro Garnacho's cross to net an 87th-minute winner.

It was by no means a vintage performance from United on the opening night of the campaign, but they did enough to get themselves over the line and secure all three points. Both sides had been guilty of wasting opportunities prior to Zirkzee's moment in the spotlight, the best of which fell to Bruno Fernandes.
Erik ten Hag will be aware that his side can be better, but there is no understating the importance of starting the campaign with three points and a clean sheet.
Below, MEN Sport has picked out some of the moments you might have missed from United's Premier League opener.

After a relatively slow and uninspiring start, United got better as the first half developed. They increased the tempo and were eventually finding some joy inside the final third after initially struggling to find a way through Fulham's midfield.

Despite being the holding midfielder, much of United's forward play was driven by Casemiro, who continues to look better in attacking scenarios than defensive ones. He pressed Fulham high and his commitment led to him sliding in on Cottagers left-back Antonee Robinson.

His determination and desire to make the challenge earned plaudits from teammate Mason Mount, who celebrated it almost like a goal, highlighting his appreciation for his midfield compatriot's commitment to the cause. The former Chelsea man then turned around and rallied the crowd, urging them to be energised by Casemiro's determination.

With the scoreline level at 0-0 as the game went into its final 10 minutes, the contest became stretched and it looked as though either side would be capable of grabbing a winner. United's best hope of finding something looked as though it would come via the energy of Garnacho - and so it nearly proved.

After shaking off Robinson, the winger got to the byline and cut the ball back for Marcus Rashford, who looked set to tap home from close range. However, Kenny Tete got just enough on it to stop it from arriving at the academy graduate's feet.
Garnacho sank to his knees and put his head in his hands. He was just as frustrated as those on the other side of the advertising hoardings.
After Zirkzee had taken a swipe at Garnacho's cross with 87 minutes on the clock, Old Trafford exploded. It had been a frustrating night, with a cluster of great opportunities being wasted.

After seeing his effort creep beyond Bernd Leno and into the bottom corner, Zirkzee wheeled away to celebrate, racing behind the net at the Stretford End. He was immediately chased after by his teammates, with Rashford the first to congratulate him.

But as the majority of United's players raced after Zirkzee to embrace him, Fernandes, after raising his arms aloft to celebrate the goal just inside the penalty area, bent forward, dropped his head and sank to his haunches.

headline: Joshua Zirkzee reveals what Erik ten Hag told him to do before scoring for Man United vs Fulham
body: Joshua Zirkzee revealed Erik ten Hag told him "to bring energy" to the team before he marked his Manchester United debut with a goal in Friday night's win over Fulham.
After stepping off the bench to make his United bow with 61 minutes on the clock, Zirkzee guided home the winner with just three minutes of regulation time remaining.

The Netherlands international, who joined United from Italian outfit Bologna last month, guided home fellow substitute Alejandro Garnacho's cross. It was the slightest of touches, but one that was enough to evade Fulham goalkeeper Bernd Leno.

Having failed to make it off the bench in the Community Shield against Manchester City at Wembley last weekend and starting the visit of the Cottagers on the bench, Zirkzee made his mark in the best possible way.
"To win here in my first home game and grab a goal, it couldn't have been better," Zirkzee told Sky Sports.

"I have been told that it is one of the best feelings here at Man United (scoring at the Stretford End) and I am just very thankful and blessed that I could experience it in my first game. It was an amazing feeling."
Asked what Ten Hag had told him to do ahead of coming on, Zirkzee continued: "To bring energy and help the team as much as possible. Just that!"

headline: Manchester United have an obvious £8m option to help solve their squad issue
body: With the new Premier League campaign officially up and running, Manchester United know time is against them in their quest to complete their transfer business.
United increased their tally of new additions to four in midweek, landing defenders Noussair Mazraoui and Matthijs de Ligt from Bayern Munich.

With less than a fortnight to go until the window closes, United are understood to be focusing on strengthening their midfield options. Paris Saint-Germain's Manuel Ugarte remains a top target and there is growing confidence a deal can be done.

As much as it is necessary for the Reds to bring in a midfielder before the bell, there also needs to be a much-needed increase in departures. Aaron Wan-Bissaka became the fifth headline departure from Old Trafford in midweek, joining West Ham United, but more are needed.

United's hierarchy planned to oversee a squad exodus this summer but that has not come to fruition. The exits of Mason Greenwood and Wan-Bissaka have been the headline acts, but United need to try and raise more funds.

Selling Victor Lindelof and Scott McTominay, who are both facing the likelihood of a reduction in minutes this season, would represent United's best hope of generating some much-needed cash out of the players they would be happy to sell before the deadline.

However, few need to leave United more than Facundo Pellistri. Since joining the club from Uruguayan outfit Penarol in 2020, he has played just 25 times, failed to score and been sent out on loan twice.

If his cameo appearance at right-back in the Community Shield at Wembley last weekend turns out to be his final outing for the club, it would sum up his United career. It is understood he was left out of the squad against Fulham at Old Trafford as he is likely to be offloaded.

Although he has offered flashes of his quality, regularly having a positive impact when he has stepped off the bench in the Erik ten Hag era, it is overwhelmingly clear that he does not have a long-term future at Old Trafford. United are bloated in the wide areas and they need to address that issue before the window shuts.

With Alejandro Garnacho and Amad closer to Ten Hag's first XI than ever before, United still hopeful of Marcus Rashford getting back to his best levels, Jadon Sancho still at Old Trafford and Antony almost impossible to shift, it makes sense for Pellistri to be moved on, both for United's sake and for the sake of his own career.

Despite struggling for regular minutes at Old Trafford, he has established himself as a regular fixture at international level with Uruguay, starting each of their six games at the Copa America earlier this summer. He has earned Marcelo Bielsa's trust and he is evidently key to his plans.
With that said, Pellistri has earned the right to establish himself as a regular first-team player elsewhere. He is only 22 and his performances for United have proven he has potential.

He has been linked with a handful of overseas clubs in recent weeks, including Italian outfit Bologna and Greek champions Panathinaikos. Spanish outfit Real Valladolid also declared interest in him at the beginning of last month.

headline: Why Jadon Sancho was not in the Manchester United squad vs Fulham
body: Jadon Sancho was not named in the Manchester United squad against Fulham partly due to an ear infection.

Sancho made his first competitive United appearance in nearly a year as a substitute in the Community Shield against Manchester City last week but he was absent from the matchday squad for the 1-0 opening Premier League win against Fulham.
United manager Erik ten Hag clarified Sancho was fit enough to be included but he opted to name Alejandro Garnacho, Joshua Zirkzee and Antony as the attacking substitutes.
"First of all, we need squad depth," Ten Hag said. "This season is the survival of the fittest but I can only put 20 players in the squad, I have to make choices.
"And Jadon in the week had an ear infection and was not 100% fit for this. He could play but if you can make choices, I made the choice that we preferred other players on the bench.

"That can change and will definitely change in the season where we have to rotate because we can’t play every game with the same. You see today how important subs are, we need the right bench and the right balance.

"Sometimes it is frustrating for the player but it’s about the team, it’s about the club, there will be more players in this position but we expect them to fight for the club. We have so many games to play, everyone will have their minutes and then they have to prove it."

United beat Fulham through debutant Zirkzee's 87th-minute prod. Zirkzee came on after 60 minutes as United squandered three great chances, having performed profligately in the 1-1 draw with City and the 3-0 friendly defeat to Liverpool in South Carolina two weeks ago.

Ten Hag reiterated United have to be more clinical. "One space that we have to fill is to kill in the box, we saw it in the friendlies, we saw it last week against City, we create enough chances not to wait for a late winner," he said.
"So we could have earlier been in the winning position. We have to be more composed and we have to kill and execute in front of the goal.
"It’s the start of the season, players have to come into full speed, we have enough players in the squad with scoring abilities and the most important thing is we created chances."

headline: Manchester United prioritising Manuel Ugarte transfer amid midfielder search
body: Manuel Ugarte remains Manchester United's top target to strengthen Erik ten Hag's midfield this summer and there is growing confidence that a deal can be done before the transfer window closes.

United have been pursuing the Paris St-Germain midfielder all summer and the Uruguayan is determined to make the move to Old Trafford, but so far there is a gap between the two clubs when it comes to a valuation.

Despite the ongoing stalemate, there is an expectation in some quarters that a deal will be done that will see the 23-year-old move to United. Ugarte has been left out of PSG's 21-man squad for the Ligue 1 opener at Le Havre this week, although new signing Joao Neves is included.

The French champions spent €60m on signing 19-year-old Neves from Benfica earlier this month and that has increased expectations that Ugarte will depart, with PSG now under some pressure to do a deal. Ugarte's preference is to move to United and talks between the two clubs are to continue.

Ugarte has always been United's priority target for that position this summer, although a lack of sales has compromised their ability to spend after a £156m outlay on Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui.

There was brief interest in Spain international Martin Zubimendi before he signalled his intention to remain with Real Sociedad, while Sofyan Amrabat could still return to Old Trafford this summer. Amrabat is set to leave Fiorentina before the closure of the transfer window.

Talks have also been held with Burnley over a move for Norway international Sander Berge, but there is other Premier League interest in the 26-year-old and talks are more advanced with other clubs. Berge has been offered guarantees over playing time that he wouldn't get at Old Trafford.

United could yet sign more than one midfielder before the window closes on Friday, August 30, but that will depend on departures. Casemiro and Christian Eriksen could still leave before the window shuts and there is significant interest in Scott McTominay.

headline: Chelsea could hand Man United welcome Jadon Sancho transfer solution to £205m problem
body: Jadon Sancho was mooted as a potential bargaining chip for Manchester United to put forward in their attempts to sign Manuel Ugarte from Paris Saint-Germain this summer. However, as it plays out, it's actually the United man who could be the ace card in a proposed swap deal in and out of Old Trafford.
Sancho to Chelsea is the sort of fantasy move Football Manager players would revel in. But, even though Chelsea are doing their best to prove otherwise, the transfer market is no computer game.

United have spent similarly haphazardly in recent years. Now that Ineos are on board, though, there's proper hope that will become a thing of the past, although that notion won't be properly proven one way or another until their new signings bed in and start producing the goods.

Noussair Mazraoui, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Joshua Zirkzee will fly the Ineos flag for the early stages of the recently-established co-ownership. There's still a whole lot of work to be done but, from here on in this summer, it will be about outgoings and generating much-needed funds for further additions.

Step forward Sancho. The ex-Borussia Dortmund forward has been re-integrated by Ten Hag this summer, despite their public spat last season, but there's every chance he could still leave Old Trafford before August 30 comes and goes if someone stumps up the right amount of cash.
Have money, will spend. That ought to be the Chelsea motto.

Reports (albeit tentative) from fussball.news indicate the Blues are about to come calling for Sancho this summer, in their latest blockbuster move, which if true presents United with a transfer conundrum. It's something Ineos will have to consider carefully - financially and otherwise - owing to past mistakes.

Among the worst spenders in elite world football for a decade, United spent more than £200million on four right wingers - namely Facundo Pellistri, Amad, Sancho and Antony - in a near-three year time frame between October 2020 and August 2023. However, while they each remain at the club, the best operator in that area is an Academy graduate who cost pennies and actually prefers to drift in from the left.

headline: How Manchester United should line up vs Fulham in opening Premier League fixture
body: Manchester United will kick off their new Premier League campaign against Fulham on Friday.

United have prepared for the new season with friendlies in Norway, Scotland and the USA, and they faced Manchester City in the Community Shield at Wembley last weekend. rik ten Hag must drastically improve the club's fortunes this term after a dismal 2023/24 league campaign and his squad has been strengthened by Sir Jim Ratcliffe in the summer window.
United have signed Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui so far, although Yoro fractured his metatarsal in pre-season and won't return until October.

The signings of De Ligt and Mazraoui from Bayern Munich were confirmed on Tuesday night and both will be included in the matchday squad to face Fulham at Old Trafford. Regarding the team news elsewhere, Luke Shaw (calf) and Rasmus Hojlund (hamstring) are unavailable and Ten Hag didn't clarify whether Victor Lindelof would return to the squad.
Here's how our writers think United should line up against Fulham...

There is absolutely no chance that Ten Hag will pick this team. De Ligt and Mazraoui would offer some balance but there is logic to only starting one of them given the fitness of Harry Maguire and Lisandro Martinez.

Casemiro and Kobbie Mainoo has to be the midfield duo as long as United go without signing a new one. Amad and Alejandro Garnacho are the in-form wingers who merit starts and Joshua Zirkzee is a striker, so has to be used sooner or later. United are fortunate Bruno Fernandes performs wherever he plays.
Steven Railston

The new season is finally here and doesn't it feel good? De Ligt's arrival was confirmed earlier in the week and he should make his debut here, starting alongside Maguire in central defence. Martinez was at left-back in the Community Shield and it's logical to stick with him in that role.
Fernandes is likely to start as a false nine again, but I'd start the club captain in his natural position and give Zirkzee, who has taken part in training for three weeks, his debut.

There is a big decision to be made on Rashford, who I think Ten Hag will start. However, Amad has been excellent in pre-season, he was one of the standout performers at Wembley last weekend and deserves to start, so I'd play Garnahco on the left and bench Rashford.
George Smith

Ten Hag has confirmed that both Mazraoui and De Ligt will be in the matchday squad, but it remains to be seen if they will start or be on the bench. However a lack of defensive options should force his hand, even if it does feel somewhat unlikely.

United have failed to recruit a new holding midfielder so far this summer, meaning Casemiro is an automatic starter. Mainoo will rightfully join him in the engine room, as should Mount, who did offer flashes of his capabilities in pre-season.

Amad and Garnacho are worthy of occupying the two wide areas after their contributions both in pre-season and at Wembley last weekend. Fernandes should lead the line again, despite Zirkzee being available and waiting in the wings.

body: Manchester United have reportedly enquired about Nottingham Forest defensive midfielder Danilo.

headline: Gary Lineker, Roy Keane, Gary Neville - Eight pundits predict Man United's season
body: Manchester United are one of the more unpredictable teams heading into the 2024/25 season.

After enduring their worst-ever Premier League campaign last term, manager Erik ten Hag remains in the dugout, but much has changed around the club. There have also been four new signings and potentially more to follow over the final fortnight of the summer transfer window.

The promising performance in the Community Shield despite a penalty shootout defeat to Manchester City also means there is growing optimism around United. Plenty of pundits have been making their predictions for the season this week, and here is a selection of them:
"I was impressed with [United] in the Community Shield," Shearer said on the Rest is Football's Premier League predictions podcast. "I thought they should have won, they had the better chances.
"They'll definitely improve their position from last year. I mean, what were they? Eighth last year? So definite improvement.
"I've got them just missing out on Champions League football, but putting up a good fight for it."

"I think they'll just miss out on [the] Champions League," Lineker said on the Rest is Football's Premier League predictions podcast. "I just wonder about a club like Man United playing counter-attacking football.

"I think it's difficult to play that way consistently, particularly against the smaller clubs. You can't play counter-attack that way, so therefore, you can't play a consistent system all season, I think that's what's scuppered them. Unless [Ten Hag] has a change of system. I'm going to say European football, but not necessarily Champions League."
"I’m actually quietly optimistic about Manchester United," Neville said on Sky Sports News. "Just generally, I think that they’re in a better situation than they were last year."
While on The Overlap's Stick to Football season preview, Neville also said: "I do [agree about United getting back into the top four]. I am not sure [on Liverpool getting top four]."

"I've got United in fourth," Richards said on the Rest is Football's Premier League predictions podcast. "I think they'll get [the] Champions League. Yeah, I was impressed with them in the Community Shield. Adding [Noussair] Mazraoui and [Matthijs] De Ligt, they're starting to get some strength in depth. So yeah, I think they can do it.

"I think [Marcus] Rashford's gonna be hungry. It's not great that [Rasmus] Hojlund's injured for the start of the season, again, but I think sometimes it helps them to play with pace on the counterattack with Rashford, [Alejandro] Garnacho and Amad as well. So I'm gonna say fourth for United this season."
“I think United are gonna be a lot better as well. Their recruitment’s been good,” Hargreaves said on TNT Sport following their coverage of the UEFA Super Cup.

"I think the very best they can do is fourth," Scholes said speaking on The Overlap’s Fan Debate. "I’ve heard a lot of Manchester United fans say how excited they are for the new season; I’m struggling to get excited for it."
Scholes added: “I think we will struggle to do as well as Liverpool, as much as I would like it to be the other way around. United have too many issues at this point to get anywhere near them.”
“Man United improving on that eighth position of last season to [the] top four,” Ferdinand said on TNT Sport following their coverage of the UEFA Super Cup.

headline: Manchester United's next transfer move will depend on which version of £60m signing turns up
body: When Casemiro's name vanished from the Manchester United team sheet between it being submitted at Wembley for the FA Cup final and then confirmed to the public it looked like a bizarre final act in his Old Trafford career.

The Brazilian had been struggling with tightness in the lead-up to the final game of the season but the 15-minute turnaround between being named as a sub and then withdrawing himself led to questions. After a difficult season, Casemiro's spot in the team was always likely to go to Sofyan Amrabat.

So difficult had his second season at Old Trafford been that it was expected Casemiro's time was up. A high-earning 32-year-old whose worth to the team had diminished was an obvious candidate to be axed by Ineos, who would never have sanctioned a £60m (rising to £70m) fee for a 30-year-old two summers ago.

The problem with that plan was finding a suitor and as interest from Saudi Arabia cooled, United were left with little option but to keep the former Real Madrid man and try and make it work. Casemiro was back at Wembley for the Community Shield last week and will start on the opening night of the Premier League season.

The signs in pre-season have been mixed. He has looked better but still far from faultless. He has had his pocket picked on a few occasions and that is a concern given he looked sluggish last season and his desire to launch into slide tackles saw him become a regular in the referee's notebook.

With no new holding midfielder in the squad, which version of Casemiro turns up will be pivotal to the early weeks of United's season? Will it be the influential leader from his first year at the club or the player who seemed to be regressing at an alarming rate last term?

You can be sure opposition teams will be targeting him early in the season. They will be closing him down quickly to see whether the speed in his game has returned for the benefit of a free summer. If he is back to his best, able to shut down attacks and get United on the front foot quickly, he remains an asset.

That is a big if, however. In an ideal world, United would have moved on from him by now. A new holding midfielder has been a target all summer. Manuel Ugarte is still determined to swap Paris from Manchester and United's interest has been live throughout the window. They briefly held an interest in Martin Zubimendi before he decided to stay with Real Sociedad.

Then there is the strange case of Amrabat, whose loan deal expired at the end of June but who is still listed as a United player on the club website. They have gone to the effort of uploading a picture of him in this season's kit, which suggests a return is more than possible.

The issue is finding the funds to make any of this happen. The anticipated number of sales hasn't come to fruition, as evidenced by the lack of a market for Casemiro. United didn't want to sell Scott McTominay but there is at least significant interest in him and a sale could add to the transfer budget, allowing another midfielder to be signed.

If Casemiro's struggles continue in the opening couple of weeks of the season, it will make finding the finance to sign an alternative even more pressing. The five-times Champions League winner might begin this season as the most important cog in the machine for Erik ten Hag.

headline: Man United receive good and bad news about Frenkie de Jong as 'club left perplexed'
body: Frenkie de Jong's relationship with Barcelona appears to be deteriorating - but for reasons Manchester United won't like.

United continue to be linked with De Jong, who was first targeted by Erik ten Hag upon his arrival in 2022. The Dutch pair worked together at Ajax - something five of Ten Hag's signings at Old Trafford have in common.

A fee was agreed with Nou Camp chiefs for the transfer, but De Jong opted to stay in Spain. His cash-strapped club have struggled to sell him as hoped because he's their highest-earning player and contracted until 2026.

Requests for the 27-year-old to renegotiate on a smaller salary have repeatedly fallen on deaf ears, which has been a constant source of frustration for them. According to AS, they suspect he's waiting to leave as a free agent at the end of his deal - which would position him well to secure another mega-money wage.
There's also said to be increasing annoyance about De Jong's injury status. The ankle injury he suffered in April's El Clasico came with an estimated recovery time of six to eight weeks.

But De Jong missed Euro 2024 with the Netherlands before returning from his holiday out of shape and with a swollen foot, it's claimed. Four months have passed and he's not expected to return before the September international break, with Barca "bewildered" at the difference in his attitude to others around him.

In stark contrast, team-mate Pedri has recovered in double-quick time from the knee problem he suffered for Spain in Germany, putting himself in contention for the start of the La Liga season. There might therefore be scope for United to try and capitalise on those issues before the summer window closes on August 30.

However, the question marks which have been raised about De Jong's attitude, as well as his injury record woes, don't correlate with the transfer approach Sir Jim Ratcliffe's team have been taking this summer. The signings of Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui appear to have been made with one eye on the future, adopting a more sensible strategy than the one used under the Glazers' rule.

Not only would De Jong not be able to make an immediate impact due to his current problem, but Barcelona's complaints about his application don't bode well long-term. Ill-discipline and injury-prone are characteristics which have plagued United teams of recent years, perhaps hence why other targets like PSG's Manuel Ugarte have been explored this summer.

headline: Man Utd must employ Leny Yoro and Mason Mount transfer trick to sign Ivan Toney
body: Manchester United could outmanoeuvre their rivals in the race for Ivan Toney's signature by disregarding his contract and meeting Brentford's financial demands.

The England star, who has expressed a desire to leave west London, has been linked with Chelsea, Tottenham and Arsenal, but Erik ten Hag's side have now entered the fray. With Rasmus Hojlund sidelined for an expected six weeks, Joshua Zirkzee - who made an immediate impact with a winner off the bench against Fulham - is his only recognised striker available.

Toney, who would bring a proven goal-scoring record to Old Trafford, could be subject to the same strategy that saw United secure Mason Mount and £58m man Leny Yoro - bidding above market rate for a player nearing the end of his contract.

Brentford are holding firm on their £60m asking price for their star player, even though he has publicly stated his readiness for a big move. United could employ the same shrewd tactic used to secure Mount and Yoro, attempting to snatch Toney for a fee while other clubs wait to sign him on a free deal next year.

With the financial support of new minority shareholder Sir Jim Ratcliffe, who has already facilitated big-money moves for £36.5m Zirkzee and £42m Matthijs de Ligt, United could meet Brentford's asking price and, as with previous transfers, win the race for Toney.

Mount made a surprise switch to Manchester United in 2023, with the Red Devils shelling out £55m for the English talent. Liverpool had been in the frame but reportedly backed out due to protracted talks with Chelsea, allowing United to swoop in.

United pulled off a similar coup this summer, snatching Yoro from Real Madrid's grasp. The defender was on course to join the Spanish giants on a free transfer in 2025, but United stepped in, agreed to Lille's £58m asking price and secured his services.

With competition heating up for Toney, United might need to employ the same aggressive strategy they used for Mount and Yoro. Brentford manager Thomas Frank expressed his desire for Toney to remain at the Gtech Community Stadium amid the speculation, telling Sky Sports post-Euro 2024: "You never know.

"He is a Brentford player. I would love him to stay. They'll give me a very positive challenge. But, you know, I haven't met a coach that didn't want as many good players as possible. So, right now, Ivan is a Brentford player.

"I know he's enjoying his time off, well deserved time off after the time with England, and I'm happy if he's here with us. I'll be more than happy at training. [He's a] goalscorer. Two things in that - that's very good to have in your team, and if someone wants to buy him, it's expensive."

headline: Manchester United can get FFP boost at a perfect time for Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United could be reaping the awards in more ways than one for work done in the club’s academy over the past few years.

Head of academy Nick Cox has been praised for his work with the youth teams since being appointed into the role in the summer of 2019. The former Watford and Sheffield United man has been credited with making massive improvements in the academy, and that is now filtering into the first team.

After impressing Erik ten Hag this time last year during pre-season, midfielder Kobbie Mainoo went onto play a key role in the season. His performances earned him a call up to the England team for Euro 2024.

The 19-year-old made a total of 32 first team appearances for United in all competitions last season, scoring five goals. He was hailed for his performance in the FA Cup final against Man City as United came out as 2-1 winners.

History could potentially repeat itself again this year with both Toby Collyer and Harry Amass impressing during pre-season so far. Both players started Sunday’s 3-0 loss against Liverpool, with Amass also being selected for the 3-2 win over Real Betis as well as the friendly vs Arsenal.

Ten Hag has shown with Mainoo that he is not afraid of putting young players in if they impress. That’s a good sign for both Collyer and Amass ahead of the new season, but their development is good news for United, even if they don’t break into the first team.

Their performances mean that clubs will be willing to pay good money if they are sold now or in the future. The fact that they are both academy graduates means that any fee made will go down as pure profit on the club’s accounts.

If that is the case, then it will be a big boost for United given the Premier League’s Profitability and Sustainability Rules (PSRs). Any pure profit made will also come at a time when United need it the most, given the club's recent record on player sales and the money needed for both the new stadium and for incoming transfers.

For United it’s win-win in terms of the improvement in the academy. The club either produces players who can make their way into the first team and reduce the need for incoming transfers, or they can sell for pure profit to boost their finances.

headline: Manchester United might start 17-year-old against Man City after 'aggressive' comment
body: How does it feel to play for Manchester United in front of thousands of fans at just 17 years old?
Just ask Harry Amass, who started against Arsenal, Real Betis and Liverpool on tour in the USA.

"I enjoy it, man," he said. "In front of the crowds, playing with the best players, I’m enjoying it. You’ve just got to show your aggressive side. You might be young, smaller than the opponent, but you have to show you are aggressive and don’t back down. Then you can have a good game."
Amass spoke to Manchester-based reporters in the mixed zone in the Snapdragon Stadium last week and a start against Liverpool in Columbia followed that conversation.

The youngster was asked about a potential start in the Community Shield against Manchester City and said: "No conversations have been had yet, but this pre-season is a chance to prove that if I am picked I can do it. Obviously we’ll see what happens when Luke [Shaw] and Tyrell [Malacia] come back.

"My intention is to play first-team football at this club. I think if the opportunity comes, I’ve got to take it with both hands, it could change my career. I am just waiting for that moment, I am ready."
Luke Shaw started for England in the final of the European Championship against Spain and has been given an extended break, while Tyrell Malacia is still recovering from injury.
Malacia last played a competitive fixture for the Netherlands in June last year and has faced a prolonged period on the sidelines due to a knee injury, which required two rounds of surgery.
The 24-year-old is expected to be available again in two months, which opens the door for Amass, and the London-born full-back intends to capitalise on the opportunity.
After just one year at United, Amass has already drawn comparisons to Shaw, who swapped the South for the North himself when he was a teenager. "It is a good comparison," he said.
"In my opinion, [Shaw is] one of the best left-backs in the Premier League, if not the best for a long time. So I am not gonna complain at the comparisons!"

United thought Shaw had the quality to play at Old Trafford for 10 years when he was signed from Southampton in 2014 and they recognised similar potential in Amass when he was signed from Watford last summer, a move that was considered a coup given the interest from other clubs.

Amass was persuaded to sign for United and hasn't looked back. He was tremendous for the Under-18s last season, playing a key role in a supremely talented team that won a treble, and is now on the cusp of making his senior debut after delivering mature pre-season performances.

Anyone who has watched Amass will understand there can be no concerns about his ability, talent or mentality. He is a technically exceptional, modern-day full-back, but the only question mark against the youngster was whether he was physical enough for senior football.
Amass is diminutive but proved himself on the pre-season tour. His 'aggression' compensates for his lack of stature and he got the better of Mohamed Salah at the weekend.
Malacia won't be involved in the squad for the Community Shield against City on Saturday and Shaw won't have the fitness to play 90 minutes at Wembley.

Amass is almost guaranteed to be involved in some capacity and that will highlight his impressive progress in the space of just a few months, as the youngster only got close to the pitch when he warmed up on the sidelines when he was last at Wembley for the FA Cup semi-final.

Erik ten Hag named Amass, Ethan Wheatley, Habeeb Ogunneye and Louis Jackson on a handful of benches at the end of last season due to the injury crisis and any observers would have noticed how slight they looked, which is normal at their age, in the pre-match warm-ups.
However, what Amass lacks in physicality, he makes up for in character, aggression and talent, so it wouldn't be a surprise to see him start against City in the Community Shield.

headline: 'I've got to take it' - the three Manchester United youngsters set for first team squad roles
body: Joe Hugill was left in the cold at Wigan, Habeeb Ogunneye warmed the bench for nine games, Toby Collyer was an unused substitute on eight occasions and Harry Amass kicked his heels on seven matchdays.

In the end, Ethan Wheatley had the privilege of becoming Manchester United's 250th academy graduate. Wheatley had been on the bench for only two games before he was summoned to replace Rasmus Hojlund for a late cameo against Sheffield United.
"Quite a few of us wanted it and we had a bit of banter about it!" Wheatley says of the 250 milestone. He is stood with Amass and Collyer, both smiling ruefully in the Snapdragon Stadium mixed zone.
Southerners Collyer and Amass are doing their utmost to extend the number to 251 as soon as possible. United expect Collyer, Amass and Wheatley to remain with the squad beyond the transfer window.

Collyer, 20, has started in three of United's four pre-season games and strapped on the captain's armband for the second half against Rosenborg. The 17-year-old Amass has lined up in both tour games in the United States.

Left back Amass followed up his invaluable 45 minutes against Arsenal in Los Angeles, where he was blindsided by Gabriel Jesus for the equalising goal, with a complete performance against Real Betis in San Diego. He capped it with an assist for Amad and drew approval from the crowd with his tenacious tackling.

"I enjoy it, man," the Londoner says. "In front of the crowds, playing with the best players, I’m enjoying it. You’ve just got to show your aggressive side, you might be young, smaller than the opponent, but you have to show you are aggressive and don’t back down. Then you can have a good game."

Amass only joined the United academy from Watford last year. Such was his importance during the run-in last season, Erik ten Hag checked on his well-being in the Carrington canteen when the academy squad returned from their title-clinching win at Wolves in April.

Luke Shaw only played 15 times for United last term and Tyrell Malacia's absence from club football is nearing 15 months. Amass could conceivably start the Community Shield against Manchester City on Saturday.

"No conversations have been had yet," he admits, "but this pre-season is a chance to prove that if I am picked I can do it. Obviously we’ll see what happens when Luke and Tyrell come back. My intention is to play first team football at this club.
"I think if the opportunity comes, I’ve got to take it with both hands, it could change my career. I am just waiting for that moment, I am ready."

Diminutive, fleet-footed and attack-minded, there are obvious parallels with the great Barcelona and Spain left back Jordi Alba. Shaw is another Cockney left back who has settled in Manchester for a decade.

Amass approves of that comparison. "It is a good comparison. In my opinion one of the best left-backs in the Premier League, if not the best for a long time. So I am not gonna complain about the comparison!"

"We have to make progress," Ten Hag said on Amass. "But we all see here a potential where we have seen in previous years, for instance two years ago, Garnacho last season. We had it during last season with Kobbie, but he (Amass) is not that far now at this moment. But if we train him well, if we coach him well, then in three months it's possible that he can be on that point.

"But in this moment he needs to catch up and he has to develop some skills already to play for Manchester United, competing for the highest positions in the league. But with big talent it can go up very quickly and that is very interesting to see if he is capable of doing this."

Collyer, signed from Brighton as an 18-year-old two years ago, trained under Ten Hag as early as September 2022. He is one of only three academy players whose contract signing Ten Hag insisted on attending. The other two were Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo.

"I think it's a massive boost," Collyer says of Ten Hag's attendance for his signing ceremony. "It shows obviously he rates me as a player. Just onwards and upwards really, just got to give my best every day and see what happens."

Collyer came on for half-an-hour at the Snapdragon Stadium and thwarted Betis twice in injury time with valiant interventions. He has acquitted himself impressively and United need to bring down the average age of their midfield department.

"When you're on the bench I think it's really valuable just to be in and around it, experience what it's like on a matchday," Collyer explains. "In the changing room, on the bench, with a crowd, getting used to it. Now I've managed to get quite a lot of minutes in pre-season, so I'm happy.

"I'd say with me, a lot of my work is off the ball as well. Predominantly, I'm a really busy player, I like to get about the pitch and an area of my game I'd like to improve on is in possession. So I think the only way you're going to get better is by demanding the ball, getting on it and not backing away from situations when you could."

Ten Hag made a beeline for Mainoo after United's League Cup victory last year and back at Wembley 15 months later, did likewise with Collyer after United won the FA Cup. "He just said take it all in, enjoy myself and keep working hard and you never know what can happen," Collyer reveals.
"He's a really good guy, the manager. With everyone, he tells you what he wants from each player, he tries his best to help you out, as well as with the other coaching staff as well.
"At the end of the day, they do everything for us and we have to put it out on the pitch and give everything for them."

Stockport-born Wheatley was one of a handful of positives from the listless defeat to Rosenborg last month. He can expect to continue training with the first team amid Rasmus Hojlund's six-week absence with a hamstring strain.

"I'm just taking everything as it comes, to be honest," he cautions. "Obviously, I had a little taste of it last season. This season, I just want to keep my head down, keep developing as a player and keep impressing, so hopefully get more chances.

"The club, its history is of bringing through loads of academy players, the likes of Kobbie, playing with us less than a year ago and breaking into the first team, inspires us and motivates us. Because we know the pathway is there. If we impress, get the chances that will be given at this club we'll take them."

Ruud van Nistelrooy has not rejoined United as a striker coach but Wheatley, born in the same year that Van Nistelrooy left United, is picking his brains. "I think especially since Ruud came in, obviously he was a top striker, he was probably one of the best strikers we've had at the club.
"As soon as he came in I've been trying to take tips off him to help develop my game."

headline: Two players can save Man United millions to create Sir Jim Ratcliffe dream transfer scenario
body: Manchester United have a number of areas that need to be improved, but the club selected three priority areas this summer.

A striker and a centre-back have arrived, while it is thought that Erik ten Hag is closing in on a new midfielder, Manuel Ugarte. While Leny Yoro’s three-month setback could push United into another centre-half signing this window, other positions may need some attention.

One of those is left-back, given how injuries decimated options there last season. Luke Shaw is back to fitness but only played 15 matches last term due to issues and is yet to go through a full season at United without injury.

Meanwhile, Tyrell Malacia is not expected to return until October, having not played in more than a year due to setbacks in his rehabilitation from serious surgery. Sergio Reguilon was acquired on loan last deadline day but returned to Tottenham in January after Ten Hag ended his stay early, with Shaw and Malacia both expected back soon. That never happened.

As a result, Diogo Dalot, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and even Victor Lindelof had to cover in the role with full-back options stretched. Sorting another loan this summer to cover for Malacia would be sensible.

But meanwhile, academy recruit Harry Amass has impressed so far in pre-season, most notably against Real Betis. The 17-year-old joined from Watford last August with big hopes for the future, and the first fruits of his potential are starting to show.

A few first-team stints this coming season followed by consistent progress, and United might not need to find a new left-back when Shaw’s contract runs out in 2027, saving a good few million. For now, third-choice at United is an ample status, and the reality is that the team might still need more experienced cover at left-back via a loanee until Malacia returns.

Another area of debate is the right-wing position. On paper, United have a number of options there, with Antony, Jadon Sancho and Marcus Rashford able to play in the role, Alejandro Garnacho too, albeit to limited effect.

In reality, the spot has hardly been nailed down in Ten Hag’s tenure, with Antony underwhelming his £85m price tag, Rashford preferring the left flank far more, and Sancho falling out with the manager, a feud that has now been quashed.

headline: Alexander Isak comparison, Arsenal fury - Man United sent exciting Chido Martin-Obi verdict
body: Manchester United are closing in on the signing of promising young talent Chido Martin-Obi after the youngster turned down a new contract at Premier League rivals Arsenal. The Gunners are said to have pulled out all the stops to tie the 16-year-old down to fresh terms, but it's United who look set to win the race for the Denmark-born striker.

Obi-Martin, who scored 29 goals in 17 league matches for Arsenal's Under-18s last year, went from strength to strength last season, notably scoring 10 goals in a single game against Liverpool. It's understood United's head of the academy, Nick Cox, and the head of academy recruitment, Luke Fedorenko, are the main driving forces behind the deal.

Once the i's have been dotted and the t's crossed, it will be a significant coup for United's youth set-up which has been undergoing a renaissance after a period of underachieving and Cox's appointment as head of academy in 2019 was a key moment.

The Manchester Evening News spoke with football.london's chief Arsenal writer Kaya Kaynak for an insight into Martin-Obi, his understanding of the deal and what sort of player he is ahead of his arrival in Manchester.

Kaya Kaynak: "It's a bit hard to say as he's still so young, but one thing he seems to be very good at is scoring goals. He's quite a bit taller than most others around his age group right now and looks stylistically a bit similar to Alexander Isak with his languid running and technical ability."
KK: "Arsenal were really keen to keep him. They pulled out all the stops and were confident of doing so after keeping other young talents like Ethan Nwaneri and Myles Lewis-Skelly in recent years.
"However, they do feel they offered all they were willing to offer. With that in mind, there's a feeling of acceptance at the decision Chido has decided to take."

KK: "Any player who scores as many goals as Chido did at such a young age is going to be thought of very highly. It's probably fair to say was viewed as one of the top three or four prospects right now.

"Arsenal are constantly using internal analytics to assess the trajectory of their players and he did look to be a promising talent. At the same time though, it's so hard to tell at 16 and many were intrigued to see how he would have coped at a higher age level."
KK: "I'd say so. There's clearly a high-potential player in there. He's someone who can score lots of goals and that's not easy to find.
"The big test for him will be seeing how he steps up through the age groups. If he manages that though, United have a real player on their hands."
KK: "I think the fact that he was in such high demand this summer tells you what a good player he is. He was wanted by clubs across Europe as well as in England."

headline: Dan Ashworth makes encouraging Man United gesture after Sir Jim Ratcliffe admission
body: Dan Ashworth has met with Manchester United Women's players after a turbulent summer for Marc Skinner's side.

United have come in for criticism of late number after a number of high-profile players, including England goalkeeper Mary Earps and captain Katie Zelem, were allowed to leave the club on free transfers, while co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe sparked controversy when he admitted plans for the women's team were "TBC".

Fan frustration was further compounded when it emerged Skinner's side were set to be moved out of their state-of-the-art training facility to accommodate the men's team while a £50m refurbishment of their Carrington facilities was underway.

However, Ashworth's long-awaited arrival from Newcastle United last month has offered some cause for optimism, with the sporting director having previously been a huge advocate for the growth of the women's game during his time with the Magpies and in his previous role at Brighton & Hove Albion. And the 53-year-old has now met with Skinner and his players as they ramp up their pre-season preparations at St George's Park.

Pictures shared on the club's website show Ashworth giving a speech to the women's first-team squad and shaking hands with stars such as Ella Toone and Millie Turner. This comes after he outlined his vision for the Reds in an open letter to supporters.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said last month. "Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United.

"Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that. Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."
United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last term and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their new campaign underway against West Ham at Old Trafford on Saturday, September 22.

headline: Manchester United confirm 'insane' summer transfer as overhaul continues
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of Canada international Simi Awujo on a three-year deal.

The 20-year-old midfielder joins the Reds from the United States collegiate system, where she represented the University of Southern California’s USC Trojans. Awujo made her senior international debut for Canada at 18-years-old and has 19 caps for her country to date, reaching the quarter-finals of this summer’s Paris 2024 Olympic games.

Reflecting on her move to Manchester, Awujo said: “To say that I’m a professional footballer for Manchester United is insane. I’m so excited for the season ahead, what the future holds here and just to be a red devil. I cannot wait to play in front of the great Manchester United fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “Simi is an exciting young talent who we are delighted has chosen to continue her football journey with us here at Manchester United. Our wonderful fans can expect a midfielder with international pedigree, who will only develop further in our competitive English game.”

Awujo is United's fifth signing of the summer following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Melvine Malard, Elisabeth Terland and Anna Sandber. The Reds finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last term and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their new campaign underway against West Ham at Old Trafford on Saturday, September 22.

headline: Mary Earps takes subtle swipe at Manchester United after PSG move
body: England goalkeeper Mary Earps says she is hoping to add "a few more trophies to the cabinet" after leaving Manchester United to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG).

Earps joined the Reds in 2019 and helped the club win the FA Cup last year. However, the shot-stopper opted to embark on a new chapter when her contract expired in June after a disappointing Women's Super League (WSL) campaign saw United finished fifth last term - 21 points worse off than in the previous campaign.

Despite being linked with a move to Arsenal, Earps chose to join PSG, who have qualified for the Women's Champions League for six consecutive seasons. Speaking on the latest episode of the BBC's Tooney & Russo Show, Earps said she has established some "great relationships" in Manchester, but her decision to leave was fueled by "the opportunity to play for a great team in top competitions" and be "in a position to win silverware".

"It's like an itch you can never scratch enough,” Earps said. And the 31-year-old's former United teammate Ella Toone, who also plays alongside Earps for the Lionesses, was full of praise for the goalkeeper.
"She deserves everything," said Toone. "Mary's dream - and it always has been - is to play at the highest level, play in the Champions League and that's what she's done."

Earps is not the only player to have left United this summer, with captain Katie Zelem and forward Lucia Garcia also having departed. Reflecting last month on her decision to move overseas, Earps wrote on Instagram: "The club is about to undergo a period of transition, and unfortunately I don’t feel it aligns with the timing of where I’m at in my career, therefore I think now is the right time to make a change and embark on a new challenge."

headline: Manchester United sign Sweden defender in record-breaking transfer
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of highly-rated Sweden international Anna Sandberg on three-year deal, with the option of a further year.

The defender joins the Reds from BK Hacken, where she had been playing since July 2022, gaining Champions League experience with the Damallsvenskan side. On the international stage, Sandberg was part of the Sweden squad that finished third at the 2023 FIFA Women’s World Cup.

She joins for what will be a record transfer fee for a Swedish women’s player, surpassing the £150,000 Everton paid to Rosengard for Hanna Bennison in 2021. The 21-year-old full-back is United's fourth signing of the summer, following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Elisabeth Terland and Melvine Malard.
“I’m very happy and grateful to sign for this big club, Manchester United," Sandberg said. "I hope I can help our team with my qualities and deliver many winning moments for our fantastic fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “We are delighted to have Anna join our Manchester United family. She is a talented young player, who already has a wealth of international and Champions League experience. We look forward to seeing her develop further in red.”

United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last season and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their 2024/25 campaign underway against West Ham United at Old Trafford on the weekend of September 21/22.

headline: Man United task clear as next England 'superstar' pens emotional Tottenham goodbye
body: As Manchester United set to work dismantling Tottenham Hotspur in the Women's FA Cup final, there was one player inside Wembley Stadium whose loyalties were split.

Grace Clinton, who joined United from Everton in 2022, had spent the season on loan at Spurs and was therefore ineligible to feature against her parent club. Her absence was a huge blow for Robert Vilahamn's side, who ultimately fell to a 4-0 defeat in north-west London as the Reds romped to their first major piece of silverware.

Clinton had been a revelation during her season-long stint at Brisbane Road, completing a clean sweep of Tottenham's Player of the Season awards and breaking into the senior Lionesses squad. "She will be the next superstar in this country if you ask me," Vilahamn said after the midfielder's impressive start to life on loan. "I think she's brilliant and has the potential to be so good."

Clinton form was so good, in fact, that Tottenham were keen to make her stay in the capital permanent. “She cannot stay because she’s not a part of us next year," Vilahamn told The Athletic in April. "But if you ask me if I want to buy her, there would be a high potential I want to do that."

The 21-year-old - who also excelled on loan at Championship side Bristol City in 2022/23 - seemed to relish her time at Spurs, forging a close friendship with teammate Celin Bizet and flourishing under the watchful eye of Vilahamn. “Confidence for me comes from the manager, and both Robert and (England boss) Sarina (Wiegman) have given me so much of that this season,” Clinton told the MEN earlier this year.
“This season I’ve just been filled with confidence and I think you can see that on the pitch. That freedom and confidence from them has allowed me to go and express myself.”

This week, however, seemed to draw a definite line under Clinton's Tottenham adventure, with the midfielder taking to social media to pen an emotional farewell to the Lilywhites. "This past year was by far my happiest season of football," she wrote on Instagram.

"I loved every minute at this club and I’ve made friends for life along the way. I’m so beyond grateful to the staff and my teammates for making this club so special to be a part of. Most importantly thank you to our fans for your unbelievable support this past year, you truly helped us make history and those are moments I will cherish with me."

While part of Clinton's heart might always belong to Spurs, her focus will now turn to transforming United into a consistent force in the Women's Super League (WSL), with the former Everton prodigy set to return to Leigh Sports Village as Marc Skinner's side ramp up their pre-season preparations. Despite beating Tottenham to the FA Cup trophy last term, the Reds faltered in the top flight, finishing in fifth place and winning just 10 of their league games.

In spite of United's turbulent campaign, manager Skinner was somewhat controversially awarded a one-year contract extension by the club's hierarchy and the 41-year-old will surely now be delighted to have Clinton to call upon as he bids to turn the Reds' WSL fortunes around.

Though he has always been unequivocal in his stance on the 21-year-old, insisting that her long-term future lies in Manchester, her return will be a huge boost for Skinner, particularly considering the club have parted company with midfield duo Katie Zelem and Irene Guerrero this summer.
"All I hear is Tottenham want to keep Grace, of course they want to keep Grace," the United boss said when quizzed on the club's plans for Clinton back in May. "She's a fantastic player.

"We don't get the credit that we identified her qualities at Everton, we brought her to Manchester United, gave her six months, sent her on loan at Bristol – she got experience. She then went on loan to Tottenham to get more experience. I don't think people recognise that – there is a plan for each individual we bring into the club.
"With Grace, it's absolutely worked. I want to bring her back to the club and be part of what we're doing because I think she has a huge say in how we'll play."

Certainly, Clinton returns to United a much more well-rounded player than when she left, having gained valuable experience on both the domestic and international stage. The midfielder won her first senior cap for the Lionesses against Austria in February and took just 19 minutes to crown her eye-catching debut with a goal.

"She plays like a natural," Wiegman said after the game. "She wants to have the ball. She picks up the things we talk about very quickly and that's what you see on the pitch too. She just goes out there and plays."
Clinton has won a further two caps over the past five months and is surely destined for many more. But it is not only on the pitch where the youngster has learnt some valuable lessons of late.

“Grace is a great girl,” Manchester City and England defender Alex Greenwood told the MEN in April. “You see her about and she's always wanting to ask questions, learn from everyone, and she's a really confident girl as well. She believes in herself and she always wants to improve, and I love that about Grace.

“She was doing a press conference and so she came up to me and Lucy (Bronze) and said: ‘What can’t I say?’ That’s just an innocent question and that’s not even about football but it’s stuff that comes hand-in-hand now with playing for the Lionesses.
“At dinner she asks questions like ‘What do you eat Al?’ I remember her first camp, we were on a walk before the game and I said: ‘Grace, you haven’t shut up this whole walk’...but it’s nice.”

While it's clear Clinton still has plenty to learn - both on and off the pitch - her return could spell very good news for United as they look to bounce back from the disappointment of last season. Her time at Spurs may have played a vital role in shaping her career to date but it is the Reds who must now help England's "next superstar" fulfil her true potential.
